The Brisbane School District graduates students who are thoughtful, prepared, and engaged citizens. Our program emphasizes conceptual understanding, teaching the Common Core State Standards through year-long themes. div.p: Dear Brisbane School District Families,
Today, March 16, the San Mateo County Health Officer issued an ORDER requiring all families to shelter in place. You can find the order HERE.

Because the health of our students, staff and families is of the utmost concern to us, we are closing all schools at the end of the day today. At this time, the plan is to continue with Distance Learning. Please continue to check your email for important communications from your teacher and principal.

Thank you to the overwhelming number of parents who offered to donate their child’s school lunch. So many families cancelled that we have opted to move all school lunches to LIPMAN SCHOOL for this week.

If you have any questions or concerns over the coming weeks, please email your school principal. You may also call 415-467-0550 or email bsd@brisbanesd.org. The voicemail and email will be checked daily and you will receive a response to your message.

Stay well!
Ronan Collver, Superintendent

p.a: ORDER OF THE HEALTH OFFICER No. C19-3 DATE ORDER ISSUED: March 13, 2020

h3.a: California Department of Public Health School guidance Notice March 7, 2020

p.strong: March 9, 2020
Dear Brisbane School District Parents, Guardians, and Staff,
Thank you, again, for your continued attention to our COVID-19 communication and your flexibility and cooperation. I hope you have had a restful weekend.

As we enter into another week of managing the potential spread of the COVID-19 virus, I want to provide you an update on our recent actions and decisions. After our county Superintendent’s meeting on March 6 with the County Health Department and Office of Education, it is clear that the next four weeks will be critical in understanding how COVID-19 is likely to spread and what steps will be necessary to control that spread.
On Thursday, Dr. Scott Morrow of the San Mateo County Health Department published

providing clear direction to cancel all non-essential large gatherings. While there are many variations of “non-essential gatherings” in the context of a school district, our COVID-19 Response Team is attempting to make good decisions in line with this directive without unnecessarily stealing away important experiences for children.

We have spent a great deal of time considering upcoming field trips, events, and assemblies . With each passing week, experts learn exponentially more about the virus, its spread, and the steps necessary to keep people safe. From now until the end of our scheduled Spring Break (April 10), I have made the decision, with the support of our COVID-19 Response Team, to cancel or postpone all field trips, events, and large indoor assemblies. Also, out of precaution, we will eliminate the sharing table at lunch. We will reassess the situation and recommendations at the end of Spring Break to determine if this cancellation needs to continue past Spring Break. This four-week pause will allow us to focus on limiting potential exposure and managing risks, while we see the direction this outbreak takes.
While some of you may be reading articles such as

a.strong: this one in the NY Times

p.strong: about “the right time” to close schools in a pandemic situation, the status of the COVID-19 outbreak in our community does not rise to the level of school closure at this time. The California Department of Education and California Department of Public Health just released

with clear guidance on when schools should consider closing down. Brisbane School District has followed each directive suggested based on the current status of spread in our area. All this said, it is your choice as a parent as to whether to keep your child home from school while it is in session. Non-illness absences will be counted as unexcused absences.

If you have general questions about COVID-19 or your family’s health, San Mateo County has developed a COVID-19 Public Call Center that can be reached by dialing 211. This line is open 24/7 and available in multiple languages. You can also text "coronavirus" to 211211 for information and updates.

I also wanted to share with you that our primary cleaning product "Buckeye Sanicare Lemon Quat" is listed as a COVID-19 Fighting Product and additional staff have been brought in to enhance our sanitation. Children and staff are encouraged to wash their hands often, especially before and after using shared devices and eating. We are also constantly encouraging students to keep their hands away from their face.
At this point, Parent -Teacher conferences are still scheduled for the week of March 23rd and Spring Break will still be March 30-April 10.

Please continue to use your site principals as your main point of contact. All three site principals are deeply involved in the planning and communication of the District’s response and are well prepared to lead us through these uncertain times. We could not have more capable leadership at our schools.
Hoping your family is and stays well,
Ronan Collver
9 de marzo de 2020
Estimados padres, tutores y personal del distrito escolar de Brisbane:
Gracias, nuevamente, por su continua atención a nuestra comunicación COVID-19 y su flexibilidad y cooperación. Espero que hayas tenido un fin de semana tranquilo.

A medida que entramos en otra semana de gestión de la posible propagación del virus COVID-19, quiero proporcionarle una actualización sobre nuestras acciones y decisiones recientes. Después de la reunión del Superintendente de nuestro condado el 6 de marzo con el Departamento de Salud y la Oficina de Educación del Condado, está claro que las próximas cuatro semanas serán fundamentales para comprender cómo es probable que se propague COVID-19 y qué pasos serán necesarios para controlar esa propagación.
El jueves, el Dr. Scott Morrow del Departamento de Salud del Condado de San Mateo publicó

proporcionando una dirección clara para cancelar todas las grandes reuniones no esenciales. Si bien hay muchas variaciones de "reuniones no esenciales" en el contexto de un distrito escolar, nuestro equipo de respuesta COVID-19 está tratando de tomar buenas decisiones en línea con esta directiva sin robar innecesariamente experiencias importantes para los niños.

Hemos pasado mucho tiempo considerando las próximas excursiones, eventos y asambleas. Con cada semana que pasa, los expertos aprenden exponencialmente más sobre el virus, su propagación y los pasos necesarios para mantener a las personas seguras. Desde ahora hasta el final de nuestras vacaciones de primavera programadas (10 de abril), he tomado la decisión, con el apoyo de nuestro Equipo de Respuesta de COVID-19, de cancelar o posponer todas las excursiones, eventos y grandes asambleas interiores. Además, por precaución, eliminaremos la mesa para compartir en el almuerzo. Volveremos a evaluar la situación y las recomendaciones al final de las vacaciones de primavera para determinar si esta cancelación debe continuar después de las vacaciones de primavera. Esta pausa de cuatro semanas nos permitirá centrarnos en limitar la exposición potencial y gestionar los riesgos, mientras vemos la dirección que toma este brote.
Mientras que algunos de ustedes pueden estar leyendo artículos como

a.strong: este en el New York Times

p.strong: sobre "el momento adecuado" para cerrar las escuelas en una situación de pandemia, el estado del brote de COVID-19 en nuestra comunidad no alcanza el nivel de cierre de la escuela en este momento. El Departamento de Educación de California y el Departamento de Salud Pública de California acaban de publicar
p.a: Orientación escolar_ Cumple con la FADA_FINAL.pdf
p.strong: con una guía clara sobre cuándo las escuelas deberían considerar cerrar. El Distrito Escolar de Brisbane ha seguido cada directiva sugerida en base al estado actual de propagación en nuestra área. Dicho todo esto, es su elección como padre si desea mantener a su hijo en casa fuera de la escuela mientras está en sesión. Las ausencias sin enfermedad se contarán como ausencias injustificadas.

Si tiene preguntas generales sobre COVID-19 o la salud de su familia, el Condado de San Mateo ha desarrollado un Centro de Llamadas Públicas COVID-19 al que se puede llamar marcando 211. Esta línea está abierta las 24 horas, los 7 días de la semana y está disponible en varios idiomas. También puede enviar un mensaje de texto con la palabra "coronavirus" al 211211 para obtener información y actualizaciones.

También quería compartir con ustedes que nuestro producto de limpieza primario "Buckeye Sanicare Lemon Quat" está catalogado como un producto de combate COVID-19 y se ha contratado personal adicional para mejorar nuestro saneamiento. Se alienta a los niños y al personal a lavarse las manos con frecuencia, especialmente antes y después de usar dispositivos compartidos y comer. También estamos constantemente alentando a los estudiantes a mantener sus manos lejos de su cara.
En este punto, las conferencias de padres y maestros todavía están programadas para la semana del 23 de marzo y las vacaciones de primavera seguirán siendo del 30 de marzo al 10 de abril.

Continúe utilizando los principales de su sitio como su principal punto de contacto. Los tres directores de las escuelas están profundamente involucrados en la planificación y comunicación de la respuesta del Distrito y están bien preparados para guiarnos a través de estos tiempos inciertos. No podríamos tener un liderazgo más capaz en nuestras escuelas.
Esperando que tu familia esté y se mantenga bien,
Ronan Collver

div.p: February 28, 2020
Chinese (简体中文) (繁体中文) Spanish (Español)
Dear Parents and Guardians,

As critical partners in our success and given the rising concerns about the spread of the coronavirus (now named COVID-19), we wanted to share the following updates. The Brisbane School District continues to work closely with the San Mateo County Health Department and the County Office of Education in monitoring the COVID-19 situation.

According to the California Department of Public Health, as of February 25, 2020, there are 10 cases of COVID-19 novel coronavirus confirmed in California by CDC lab testing and approximately 200 persons have been tested to date.

You may already be aware that the Centers for Disease Control (CDC) has issued new travel warnings for South Korea, Japan, and Italy. Travel warnings for China have not changed, and the CDC has lowered their level of concern for travel to Hong Kong and Taiwan. Additional details about these warnings can be found on the CDC website.

The CDC also recently shared that the coronavirus may begin spreading in communities in the United States, and Americans should begin preparations. This is why we are working with county school and health officials to review protocols for schools in the event that coronavirus spreads in San Mateo County. We will share more information as our preparations advance. In the meantime, current information about the coronavirus is available on the CDC, San Mateo County Health Department, and San Mateo County Office of Education websites.

On all our school campuses, we continue to be vigilant in cleaning common areas such as bathrooms, water faucets, classrooms, playground equipment, and cafeteria to minimize the spread of germs. We provide our staff and students with regular reminders about staying home when sick and following sound hygiene and health practices as listed below.

As a reminder to our families, if your child is sick, please keep them home from school. To help prevent the spread of respiratory viruses, including the coronavirus and the flu, follow these important tips:

li.p: Wash your hands often with soap and water for at least 20 seconds. If soap and water are not available, use an alcohol-based hand sanitizer.
Avoid touching eyes, nose, and mouth with unwashed hands.
Avoid close contact with people who are sick.
Cover a cough or sneeze with a tissue, then throw the tissue in the trash.
Clean and disinfect frequently touched objects and surfaces.
Individuals with chronic health issues and/or individuals experiencing severe symptoms should be evaluated by a medical professional.

div.p: The California Department of Public Health does not recommend the use of face masks for general prevention and says that handwashing provides much better protection from infectious diseases.
The Brisbane School District will continue to monitor the situation and provide updates as necessary. We thank you for your cooperation and support.
Sincerely,
Ronan Collver, Superintendent

div.h1: Public Health Update February 2020 re: Coronavirus (English) (Simplified Chinese) (Traditional Chinese)

p.span: The Brisbane School District graduates students who are thoughtful, prepared, and engaged citizens. Our program emphasizes conceptual understanding, teaching the Common Core State Standards through year-long themes. With an emphasis on higher order thinking skills, we focus on understanding, evaluating, and creating. We thread Lifeskills throughout our curriculum with the goal of providing our children the tools for citizenship and life.
